Among the thousands of projects undertaken to reconstruct Iraq, one case offers a good microcosm of the challenges and missteps that have bedeviled the multi-billion dollar rebuilding effort.
In mid-2004, a California construction company, Parsons Inc., was given a project to built 151 primary health care centers across Iraq.
The clinics were part of broader, ambitious effort to give all Iraqis top quality medical care.
The $200 million contract was awarded by the Army Corps of Engineers.
Parsons used Iraqis sub-contractors, which usually hired local people to do the work.
Ernie Robbins is senior vice president with Parsons, says the projected number of clinics began to dwindle quickly.
Well about 10 were deleted up front for some of those site-condition problems.
Others, because when the government said go build this clinic in this location, either the local residents or the ministry of health said we don't want you to build a clinic there.
Robbins says one U.S.
government project manager would approve designs and timeframes - then that manager would be rotated out of Iraq.
Another would come in and reverse many of those decisions.
Robbins says that confused the process and caused delays on the construction sites.
Robbin says then the violence from the insurgency and sectarian fighting started to get very serious.
As the situation deteriorated, it became less and less possible even for site visits for an hour or two to oversee the sub-contractors.
We could not send expats out there.
And so we used Iraqis who we trained to do that for us.
